text:
is there a best practice for propagating changes among registered dependent packages?

I have a registered packages `FooDep` which depends on my other package `Foo`. I’ve been making changes to `Foo`, registering and waiting, then updating `FooDep` to use the new version of Foo. This works ok, but is there a way to avoid the registration wait time?

elements.text:
is there a best practice for propagating changes among registered dependent packages?

I have a registered packages
FooDep
which depends on my other package
Foo
. I’ve been making changes to
Foo
, registering and waiting, then updating
FooDep
to use the new version of Foo. This works ok, but is there a way to avoid the registration wait time?

text: best to do that sequentially, registration merges into the global registry and that needs to occur for the dependency before it happens with the other file -- assuming there is change of version numbers happening.  Otherwise, your attempt to register could fail.

elements.text: best to do that sequentially, registration merges into the global registry and that needs to occur for the dependency before it happens with the other file -- assuming there is change of version numbers happening.  Otherwise, your attempt to register could fail.

text: As pkg registrations proceed in the order submitted (where there are no problems with the submission), if you are certain that both pkg revisions are correct (local build and test, for a start) you could use JuliaRegistrator first with the one to be registered first and when you get the "ok to merge / merge pending" message back, then do the same with the other file.  That would save you some time.  If you choose to do so, tread lightly. (I take the long way around).

elements.text: As pkg registrations proceed in the order submitted (where there are no problems with the submission), if you are certain that both pkg revisions are correct (local build and test, for a start) you could use JuliaRegistrator first with the one to be registered first and when you get the "ok to merge / merge pending" message back, then do the same with the other file.  That would save you some time.  If you choose to do so, tread lightly. (I take the long way around).

text: Thanks! Good to know I should just be patient.

elements.text: Thanks! Good to know I should just be patient.

text: Still, it would be nice on the long run to be able to register a set of dependent packages. I manage with a set of 4 at the moment, and it is a bit annoying, but it is likely to become 6-7 soon (because the dependencies are shared with other packages that I don't manage). It is gonna be a pain ^^

text:
Yes ... It is painful, as I can't concentrate on other tasks while waiting ><
I also use the safe way (now) as I had a hell of a nightmare with the fast way once.

text: Hmm... I’ve never thought about this problem. So, when there is a linear dependency such as A <- B <- C, then these new packages must be registered linearly and it would take 9 days to complete?

elements.text: Hmm... I’ve never thought about this problem. So, when there is a linear dependency such as A <- B <- C, then these new packages must be registered linearly and it would take 9 days to complete?

text: yes, though updating previously registered packages seems to be faster.

elements.text: yes, though updating previously registered packages seems to be faster.

text: Right, updates are less of a problem as it’s automated and done frequently.

elements.text: Right, updates are less of a problem as it’s automated and done frequently.
